javaslang.algebra

Interface Monad<T,M extends HigherKinded<?,M>>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - component type of this monad
    M - placeholder for the type that implements this
    All Superinterfaces:
    Functor<T>, HigherKinded<T,M>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Arbitrary<T>, Gen<T>, List<T>, Option<T>, Seq<T>, Stream<T>, Traversable<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Either.LeftProjection, Either.RightProjection, List.AbstractList, List.Cons, List.Nil, None, Some, Stream.AbstractStream, Stream.Cons, Stream.Nil

    public interface Monad<T,M extends HigherKinded<?,M>>
extends Functor<T>, HigherKinded<T,M>
    Defines a Monad by generalizing the flatMap function.

    All instances of the Monad interface should obey the three control laws:

    • Left identity: unit(a).flatMap(f) ≡ f a
    • Right identity: m.flatMap(unit) ≡ m
    • Associativity: m.flatMap(f).flatMap(g) ≡ m.flatMap(x -> f.apply(x).flatMap(g)
    given
    • an object m of type HigherKinded<T, M>
    • an object a of type T
    • a constructor unit taking an a and producing an object of type M
    • a function f: T → M
    To read further about monads in Java please refer to What's Wrong in Java 8, Part IV: Monads.
    Since:
    1.1.0

    • Method Detail

      • flatMap

        <U,MONAD extends HigherKinded<U,M>> Monad<U,M> flatMap(Function<? super T,? extends MONAD> f)
        Returns the result of applying f to M's value of type T and returns a new M with value of type U.
        Type Parameters:
        U - component type of this monad
        MONAD - placeholder for the monad type of component type T and container type M
        Parameters:
        f - a function that maps the monad value to a new monad instance
        Returns:
        a new Monad instance of component type U and container type M
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if f is null

      • flatten

        <U> Monad<U,M> flatten()
        Flattens a nested, monadic structure. Assumes that the elements are of type HigherKinded<U, M>

        A vivid example showing a simple container type: 

         
 [[1],[2,3]].flatten() = [1,2,3]
        Type Parameters:
        U - component type of the resulting Monad
        Returns:
        A monadic structure containing flattened elements.

      • flatten

        <U,MONAD extends HigherKinded<U,M>> Monad<U,M> flatten(Function<? super T,? extends MONAD> f)
        Flattens a nested, monadic structure using a function.

        A vivid example showing a simple container type: 

         
 // given a monad M<T>
 [a,[b,c],d].flatten( Match
    .caze((M m) -> m)
    .caze((T t) -> new M(t))
 ) = [a,b,c,d]
        Type Parameters:
        U - component type of the resulting Monad
        MONAD - Monad type
        Parameters:
        f - a function which maps elements of this monad to monads of the same kind
        Returns:
        A monadic structure containing flattened elements.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if f is null
